author: China Daily
title: Cold Dew: What you need to know about China's autumn crop season
text: More news, analysis and features at China Watch The traditional Chinese lunar calendar divides the year into 24 solar terms. Cold Dew, (Chinese: 寒露), the 17th solar term of the year, begins this year on 8 October and ends on 23 October. At this time, temperatures are much lower than in White Dew in most areas of China. The dew is greater and colder and there is less rain. Autumn crops will be ripe. Here are eight things you should know about Cold Dew. 1. Foggy autumn Drops of autumn: Water vapor in the air turns to misty rain or fog Photo: File image Temperatures drop significantly in October. When the cold air encounters autumn rain, the abundant water vapor in the air soon reaches saturation, and then it turns into misty rain or fog. When the humidity is high, there will be foggy regions formed in many areas of China. 2. Season for fishing Easy pickings: Fish swim to shallow waters in autumn Photo: File image People always say that fishing in shallow water in autumn does make sense. That’s because during the Cold Dew period, temperatures decrease quickly and sunshine cannot reach the deep water thoroughly. Fish all swim to shallow waters where the water temperature is relatively high. 3. Season for eating pomegranates In season: Pomegranates on a tree Photo: Sun Yang/asianewsphoto.com Pomegranates are ripe during Cold Dew. Pomegranates have been cherished for their exquisite beauty, flavor, colour, and health benefits for centuries. 4. Season for drinking chrysanthemum wine Young people in Han-style clothing taste chrysanthemum wine Photo: Zheng Shuai/asianewsphoto.com Chrysanthemum is the iconic flower of Cold Dew. To prevent autumn dryness, many regions in China have the custom of drinking chrysanthemum wine. This is a tradition of the Double Ninth Festival (on the ninth day of the ninth month in the Chinese calendar), which often falls around Cold Dew. According to ancient records, drinking the wine made with chrysanthemums, poria cocos and pine oleoresin grants people long-lasting youth. 5. Season for eating hawthorns Pick of the crop: Freshly-harvested hawthorns Photo: Si Wei/asianewsphoto.com There is a saying that goes: “It is time to harvest hawthorn during Cold Dew.” Extracts of the berries have long been used in herbal medicine. The antioxidants in hawthorn are thought to boost heart health by strengthening blood vessels and stimulating blood flow. 6. A great time for hiking Vibrant colours: Red leaves in Beijing's Fragrant Hills Park Photo: Li Wenming/asianewsphoto.com During Cold Dew, North China takes on a look of late autumn with white clouds, red leaves and early frost. On the day of the Double Ninth Festival, people often climb hills with cornels, a kind of plant. This custom aims to dispel evils, and originated in the Eastern Han Dynasty (AD25-220). 7. Season for making kippers Speciality dish: Kippers made in Qiandongnan Miao and Dong Photo: qdn.cn People of the Dong ethnic group in western Hunan province have the custom of making kippers during Cold Dew. It is said that kippers made on the day of Cold Dew with accessory foods such as rice wine, salt, glutinous rice, pepper powder, paprika powder and ginger are especially delicious. 8. Season for picking camellia seeds Villagers look at camellia seeds to be picked in Nanshan village, Hunan province Photo: Li Aimin/asianewsphoto.com Southern Hunan province is a famous area for producing tea seed oil. People are not allowed to go to the mountains to pick the seeds until Cold Dew comes around. This article was originally produced and published by China Daily .
